p:
Clark, in 1952, conducted studies depicting the potential anti-microbial activity of CQ by effective inhibition of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) synthesis on a protozoan parasite, Plasmodium gallinaceum.
13 This led to further investigations by Schellenberg and Coatney in 1960,
14 who demonstrated CQ-induced inhibition of the incorporation of radioactively labelled nucleic acid substituents in DNA and ribonucleic acid (RNA) of Plasmodium gallinaceum. These studies showed that CQ could inhibit the nucleic acid, and this nucleic-acid inhibitory potential could be utilised in viruses.
